The name is deciphered in CIJno. 1226, but a photograph of the inscription is mistakenly reproduced in no. 1215.

person.note: This is the way this king’s name is recorded in rabbinic literature. In Tacitus he is recorded as “Agrippa,” see Introduction 2.8.2.
So his name appears on a Nabatean inscription. It is not clear from the inscription whether Agrippa I or II is intended.
This is the way this king’s name is recorded in all Greek documents. The Latin name is always recorded in Greek thus (WGE, 14).
Probably named after Augustus’ friend (e.g. Kokkinos, Herodian Dynasty, 271-2). On Herodians see Introduction 1.2.4.4.
On dating according to Josephus see Introduction 7.2.

See below, n. 5.

One wonders whether this עקילס isidentical with the famous proselyte who translated the Bible into Greek. The way he appears here in tannaitic literature (the first and only time) without the title גר (proselyte) suggests that perhaps not. He is, however, mentioned here in association with the place פונטוס (=Pontus), the proselyte’s place of origin according to Eusebius (Eus. EH 5:8).
This is his only appearance in tannaitic literature, and it has no chronological indicators, see Introduction 7.5.1.4.

So in rabbinic literature. The Bible translator, is mentioned frequently in the works of many Church fathers, as “Aquila,” e.g. in the ancient translation to Latin of Irenaeus of Lyon, Adversus Haereses 3:24. Usually vowels at the beginning of words (both in Greek and Latin) are transliterated with the Hebrew א, but here ע is clearly evident. All other such cases are doubtful. However, it seems to have been an accepted transliteration in Hebrew, see עקילא in 4Q341 (=DJD36, 292).
So in Eusebius.

In Hebrew – הגר. In PT Aquila the proselyte is mentioned nine times (yDemai 6:7, 25d; yShab 6:4, 8b; yYoma 3:8, 41a; ySuk 3:8, 53d; yMeg 1:9, 71c; 2:1, 73b; yHag 2:1, 77a; yMQ 3:7, 83b; yQid 1:1, 59a). In seven instances (excluding yDemai 6:7, 25d and yHag 2:1, 77a) the text deals with the translation of the Torah. The case of yDemai 6:7, 25d is different, however, since it is parallel to a tradition from the Tosefta (tDemai6:13) where the proselyte involved is called אונקלוס. That proselyte is mentioned often in the Tosefta (tShab 7:18; tHag 3:3; tKel BB2:4; tMiq 6:3) but never in association with the Torah translation. The Tosefta, further, knows of no עקילס. In BT only the name אונקלוס is recorded and he is associated with the translation of the Torah, as well as appearing in a parallel tradition to that of the Tosefta (bAZ 11a=tShab7:18). The two seem to have been confused as time went by, but it is doubtful whether, to begin with, the two were indeed the same person.
And other church fathers after him.
On proselytes in this corpus see Introduction 6.3.3.
Described in this tradition as a contemporary of R. Eliezer and R. Joshua, see Introduction 7.5.2.

This person’s name appears four time in Vita (66, 67, 69, 296), always spelt thus, but only once (69) with a patronymic. Schalit identifies him with Capellus no. 1, but he is never named by the two names and the spelling of the name is different.
See above, n. 4.

This could be an abbreviated version of this Latin name. On the suffix see Introduction 2.4.1.7. A person named גביני בן חרסון is mentioned in Ecc Rab4:8, but not included in this corpus because the rabbis state that on his death the Persian King Belteshazzar was born, i.e. he is dated to the Persian period. On the other hand, גבין means “eyebrow, eyelash” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 206), גבינא means “humpback” (Jastrow, ibid.) and גבינה means “milk curdle” in Hebrew, (ibid.).
In Hebrew – כרוז.
Associated with the Temple, see Introduction 7.5.1.1.

This Latin name is usually transliterated into Greek as Γάϊος (WGE, 236). This seems to be a variation on the name. For the interchange of ο and ω see Introduction 2.3.3.1. The declension is recorded in the document. On such extended declensions see Introduction 2.3.5.

If the word Βερνικέος, appearing after his name, indicates that he is a native of the city of Berenice, than he is a native of Cyrene, see Introduction 6.3.1. However, it could be an unusual declension of the name Berenice, and see Berenice no. 6.

I assume this is the Hebrew transliteration of this name. The א prefix is a mistake, imitating the א added in Greek names beginning with a cluster that are transformed into Semitic languages such as אכסניה for ξενία or איצטדיון for στάδιον. Here, of course there is no cluster. The form פטרוקי, with no א prefix is found for an amora (yYoma 4:2, 41d). Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1159, also interprets this name as Patricius. Note, however, that in Gen Rab 94:7 the word אפטריקא/אפוטריכא is used for the Greek πατριάρχης.
Described in this tradition as a tanna, see Introduction 7.5.2.
This is the way this Latin name is recorded in Greek documents (WGE, 1150).

This Hebrew name seems to reflect the Roman pax. This is probably a name of this sort. Zunz, Namen, 17, suggested the Greek name Πύξις here. This name, however, is only recorded in WGE, 1288, as occurring once in a doubtful source. LPGN II, 388, records the names Πύξων and Πύξονος.
See Introduction 7.5.1.4.
This is the way this Latin name is recorded in Greek documents (WGE, 1221).

For the idea that this person should be identified with the mishnaic אבטליון, see Derenbourg, Essai, 149; Schlatter, HN 121-2; Feldman, JQR 49 (1958-9) 53-62. The idea that he should perhaps be identified with הלל was put forward by Lehmann, REJ24 (1892) 68-81, see Introduction 3.3.
On dating according to Josephus see Introduction 7.2.

On names with Ποπ being Latin derivations see WGE, 1235-6. It mentions this particular name but does not relate it to any specific Roman name. It could be Poplas. Alternatively it could be a name like Publius with an Aramicized abbreviated ending, see Introduction 2.4.2.10.
The AJversion has Πτόλλας here, but see Schwartz, JJS50 (1999), against Broshi, JJS 49 (1998).
See Introduction 6.3.2.
On dating according to Josephus see Introduction 7.2.
This seems to be the Greek of a Latin name like this. The declension is recorded in the document.

This Latin name is recorded in Greek documents as Κοδρᾶτος (WGE, 684). This form seems near enough. On this being, perhaps a Semitic suffix, see Introduction 2.4.3.
In Greek – προπεφητευκότας; ἐν Φιλαδελφίᾳ.

Although he is mentioned with other apostles, who were certainly Jews, here and in 5:17 (Judas [probably no. 23], Hagaba [no. 1], Sheila [no. 5] and Philip [no. 6]’s daughters) there is no indication that he too was Jewish, see Introduction 6.3.2.
Described by Eusebius (EH 3:34) as active in the time of the emperor Trajan (97-117 CE).

This is the suggested reading of the editor. DJD 2, 220, interpreted this name as signifying the person’s place of origin – Cyrene. My assumption that this is Qurinius is based on Josephus’ and the NT’s transliteration of the latter as Κυρήνιος (e.g. BJ 2:433; Luke 2:2).
The name could also be construed as a nickname, see Introduction 6.1.1.
On dating of ossuaries see Introduction 7.6.1.
This is the suggested reading of the editor, see above, n. 2.

Galan states specifically that Rufus was Jewish, but his place of residence makes this claim suspect. On Samaritans in this corpus see Introduction 6.3.4.

Σειλωνιανός is the Greek transliteration of the Latin Silonianus (WGE, 1359). On the ει suffix, see Introduction 2.1.2.2. The name סילן is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 336).
For dating of the Dead Sea documents see Introduction 7.7.

The Greek transliteration for the Roman emperor’s name is Τιβέριος (WGE, 1521).
This may be a father’s name (or a feminine form of the name, or a second, Latin name of the women), but it could also be an indication of the place of origin of the interned – the city of Tiberias.
For dating of this cave see Introduction 7.6.5.
WGE, 1533, mentions this Greek-spelt name in a Latin context but fails to suggest that it is a Latin name.
See Introduction 6.3.2.

WGE, 1540, mentions Τόλλιος as the Latin “Tullius.” This is near enough.
On dating of ossuaries see Introduction 7.6.1.
This is the suggested reading of the editor. This is the Greek form of this Latin name (WGE, 1084).
On second names see Introduction 6.1.3.
On dating of the Dead Sea documents see Introduction 7.7.

This is probably the genitive recorded in the document. According to WGE, 207, the Latin name Verres is transliterated into Greek as Βέρρης. The form Βεροῦς is recorded in several Egyptian papyri (Preisigke, NB, 74, who claims this is a feminine name). Alternatively, this could be the ethnic designation of Azariah, suggesting he came from Beirut. The name of this city is traditionally transcribed Βηρυτός or Βηρούθ (WGE, 209). Other transliterations are also possible, and in light of the geographical origin of the other persons interned in this cave (see under Ariston no. 4 G/M; Eiras no 2 G/F), this is certainly a plausible interpretation.
Another possible interpretation is that this is a nickname, see Introduction 6.1.1. In this case the nickname may be a place name, see above, n. 2.
On dating of ossuaries ,see Introduction 7.6.1.

According to WGE, 1090, Ο̓εττ serves for the Latin “Vet”, see Ο̓εττιανός (Vettianus) and Ο̓έττιοςVettius). The suggestion that this is the Latin name Vettenus was already put forward by T. Reinach, “L’inscription de Théodotos,” REJ 71 (1920) 51-2.
In Greek – Θ[ε]όδοτος Ο̓ετττήνου ἱερεὺς καὶ ἀ[ρ]χισυνάγωγος υἱὸς ἀρχισυν[αγώ]γ[ο]υ.
On dating of inscribed Jewish material from Jerusalem see Introduction 7.6.2.
I assume this is the Hebrew transliteration of this Latin name. Jastrow, DTTBYML, 374, assumes either the Greek Ο̓άλης or the Latin Valens.
These are other versions recorded in the mss.
In yGit 6:9, 48b he is described as a contemporary of Rabbi (Judah the Patriarch), see Introduction 7.5.2.
This is the way this Latin name is recorded in Greek documents (WGE, 1095).
See Introduction 6.3.2.
On dating according to Josephus see Introduction 7.2.

div.note: Latin gentilium, cognomen and praenomen, RNGCL, 10, 290; Chase, HSCP8 (1897) 135. Agrippa was the name of Augustus general and friend, who also visited the East, see Introduction 1.3.1.
Latin cognomen, RNGCL, 292. The name אנם is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 80).
Latin gentilium, see RNGCL, 17. Anthony was the name of the Roman general who ruled Palestine from Egypt between 40 and 30 BCE see Introduction 1.3.1.
Latin gentilium, cognomen and praenomen, RNGCL, 19, 294; Chase, HSCP8 (1897) 135.
Latin gentilium, RNGCL, 56. Claudius was the name of the Roman Emperor between 41 and 54 CE, see Introduction 1.3.1.
Latin gentilium and cognomen, RNGCL, 84, 336. The name was known in Palestine because of the presence of Gabinius, Pompey’s lieutenant, between 57 and 54 BCE, see Introduction 1.3.1.

Latin gentilium, cognomen and praenomen, RNGCL, 85, 336; Chase, HSCP8 (1897) 135. Gaius was the praenommen of Julius Caesar and the emperor Caligula and was in general popular in the Julio-Claudian family, see Introduction 1.3.1.
Latin gentilium, RNGCL, 98. Julius was the gentilium of Julius Caesar and the entire Julio-Claudian dynasty, see Introduction 1.3.1.

Latin gentilium and cognomen, RNGCL, 99, 347. In S of S Rab 4:13 the name יוסטוס is interpreted as a popular transliteration of יוסף, but we have no concrete example to prove it, and see also Klein Lĕšonénu1 (1929) 326-7. Mussies, “Jewish Personal Names,” views it both as a homophone of the biblical name יוסף and a translation of צדוק. See Introduction, 1.3.2.

Latin gentilium, RNGCL, 105. In S of S Rab 4:13 the name לוליאני is interpreted as a popular transliteration of שמעון, but we have no concrete example to prove it, and see also Klein Lĕšonénu1 (1929) 326-7, although for an interesting connection between the two names see Lollianus no. 2. See also Introduction 1.2.2.
Latin gentilium, cognomen and praenomen, RNGCL, 107, 354; Chase, HSCP8 (1897) 135.
Latin gentilium, cognomen and praenomen, RNGCL, 112, 358; Chase, HSCP8 (1897) 135.
Latin cognomen and praenomen, RNGCL, 363; Chase, HSCP8 (1897) 135. Nero was the name of the Roman emperor between 54 and 68 CE, see Introduction 1.3.1.
Latin gentilium, RNGCL, 129. The name could alternatively be the Latin gentilium Nomecius (ibid. 127).
Latin cognomen and praenomen, RNGCL, 376; Chase, HSCP8 (1897) 135.

Latin gentilium and cognomen, RNGCL, 158, 394. In S of S Rab 4:13 the name רופוס is interpreted as a popular transliteration of ראובן, but we have no concrete example to prove it, and see also Klein Lĕšonénu1 (1929) 326-7. See also Introduction 1.2.3.
Latin gentilium, cognomen and praenomen, RNGCL, 186,412; Chase, HSCP8 (1897) 135. Tiberius was the name of the Roman emperor between 14 and 37 CE, see Introduction 1.3.1.
